p: Over the past decade a growing number of vulnerability assessments have emerged from the scientific literature that focus on assessing the vulnerability of various sectors, including agriculture to climate change [ 18, 19, 20]. A number of studies [ 21, 22, 23] have adopted the well-established IPCC [ 24, 9] definition of vulnerability which can be reflected in “the extent to which a natural or social system is susceptible to sustaining damage from climate change impacts, and is a function of exposure, sensitivity and adaptive capacity” [ 22]. The impact of climate change on agriculture and livelihoods therefore can be conceptualized as the aggregation of these components [ 19].
